Graphical abstract This review highlights recent progress in utilizing in situ liquid cell TEM characterization technique in investigating the real-time growth mechanisms of the formation of core–shell nanostructures, including one-pot synthesis, seed-mediated overgrowth, Kirkendall effect, galvanic replacement, corrosion and dealloying. Metal-based core-shell nanostructures have garnered enduring interest due to their unique properties and functionalities. However, their growth and transformation mechanisms in liquid media remain largely unknown because they lack direct observation of the dynamic growth process with high spatial and temporal resolution. Developing the in situ liquid cell transmission electron microscopy (TEM) technique offers unprecedented real-time imaging and spectroscopy capabilities to directly track the evolution of structural and chemical transformation of metal-based core–shell nanostructures in liquid media under their working condition. Here, this review highlights recent progress in utilizing in situ liquid cell TEM characterization technique in investigating the dynamic evolution of material structure and morphology of metal-based core–shell nanostructures at the nano/atomic scale in real-time. A brief introduction of the development of liquid cells for in situ TEM is first given. Subsequently, recent advances in in situ liquid cell TEM for the fundamental study of growth mechanisms of metal based core–shell nanostructures are discussed. Finally, the challenge and future developments of metal-based core–shell nanostructures for in situ liquid cell TEM are proposed. Our review is anticipated to inspire ongoing interest in revealing unseen growth dynamics of core–shell nanostructures by in situ liquid cell TEM technique. Keywords In situ liquid cell TEM Metal-based core–shell nanostructures Growth mechanisms 1 Introduction Recent decades have witnessed remarkable progress in metal-based core–shell nanostructures with well-defined shapes and controllable compositions for varied applications, such as environmental science, catalysis, optics, energy, etc. [1–5]. Compared to those of bulk metal materials, metal-based core–shell nanoparticles showed outstanding properties with versatility, tunability, and stability [6–10]. The properties of core–shell nanoparticles can be easily and dramatically tuned by changing the shape, size, components and morphology of the core, as well as the shape, thickness, and components of shell materials [10–15]. Thus, understanding the growth principles of the metal-based core–shell nanostructure is beneficial for designing novel core–shell materials. Currently, the two major wet-chemical routes for achieving these core–shell materials are one-pot synthesis and seed-mediated growth by ex situ study [16,17]. They all followed the rule: the metal core was first reduced, and then the second materials were reduced due to their different redox potentials. During the process, there are three different growth modes: layer-by-layer growth, island growth, and island-onwetting-layer growth. Some researchers also proposed kinetic and thermodynamic controlled synthesis of the core–shell via atom diffusion and deposition. These proposed theories of core–shell structure formation are highly based on ex situ studies or the indirect quench-and-look approach, where the reactions are stopped at different times and the intermediate products are characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM). These approaches lack the time resolution to describe growth processes. Long-lasting questions were not answered: How can atoms come together to form an island of material support? How do nanoparticles transform or assemble to produce core–shell structures with unique shapes? How do ligands in precursors modify their growth pathways to achieve different metal-based core–shell structures morphologies? In situ liquid cell TEM characterization technique has been a powerful platform for directly observing physical, chemical, and biological processes in solution [18–24]. For example, nanoparticle nucleation growth [25], self-assembly [26], electrodeposition [27], electrode–electrolyte interfaces [28] and biomineralisation beyond [29]. In particular, studying the formation of metal-based core–shell nanoparticles would uncover complex processes and develop existing theories via alternative pathways [30–36]. Therefore, the in situ liquid cell TEM is the most promising characterization tool for real-time imaging the growth of metal based core–shell nanostructures in their natural liquid environment. Although some review papers describe diverse topics on liquid cell TEM, most of which mainly focus on nanoparticle growth and self-assembly, electrochemistry, and biology [23,26,37–39]. Up to date, an exhaustive review summarizing the advances of growing metal-based core–shell nanostructures has not been outlined in a comprehensive manner, which is of paramount importance for understanding the growth and transformation mechanisms. To this end, we highlight the utilization of in situ liquid cell TEM techniques in studying the structural and chemical dynamics of metal-based core–shell nanostructures under their working conditions. We begin with a brief introduction to the development of liquid cells for in situ liquid cell TEM studies. Then, we summarize the current application of in situ liquid cell TEM/STEM to study the real-time growth mechanisms of the formation of core–shell nanostructures, including one-pot synthesis, seed-mediated overgrowth, Kirkendall effect, galvanic replacement, corrosion, and dealloying (Fig. 1 ) [30–36]. Finally, we discuss the present challenges and opportunities on in situ liquid cell TEM study to understand the dynamic growth mechanisms of metal-based core–shell nanostructures. 2 The development of liquid cells for in situ TEM observation The concept of in situ liquid cell TEM can be traced back to the 1930s. In 1934, Marton employed the sandwiched thin aluminum foil to image biological samples [40]. In the next several decades, there were limited in situ liquid cell TEM activities because it is hard to control the liquid thickness under a high vacuum environment in TEM. Until 2003, Ross and co-workers introduced microelectron mechanical system (MEMS) techniques to create a two-electrode electrochemical liquid cell with the silicon nitride (SiN x ) electron transparent windows (Fig. 2 A) for observing the electrochemical Cu deposition process in real-time [41]. Due to the liquid thickness over 1 mm between electron transparent windows (50 nm), the best imaging resolution is only 5 nm. Afterward, Zheng et al. developed a thinner SiN x liquid cell to track the dynamic nanocrystal growth trajectory in 2009 (Fig. 2B) [42]. The group pushed the SiN x electron transparent windows to 25 nm or thinner and the liquid thickness to about 200 nm so the imaging resolution achieved sub-nanometer. The work firstly opened the unprecedented opportunity to image the growth mechanisms of nanoparticles. Simultaneously, N. de Jonge designed a flow liquid cell (Fig. 2C) for imaging single molecules in complete cells [43]. Though the flow liquid cell allowed the fresh liquid environment and minimized the electron beam effect, the sample would drift, and imaging resolution was limited. To achieve atomic resolution, Yuk et al. introduced the graphene liquid cell (Fig. 2D) to enable the study of Pt nanocrystal formation, site-selective coalescence, and structural reshaping in 2012 [44]. The graphene liquid cell is based on the entrapment of a liquid film or tiny droplets of liquids enclosed between the two thin graphene sheets. As the thinnest material, graphene liquid cell allows imaging with unprecedented high resolution, which represents a significant advancement in the development of the liquid cell. Later on, Utkur Mirsaidov’s group made a heater flow liquid cell (Fig. 2E) to study the galvanic replacement reactions at 2017 [33]. The heater liquid cell has two chips, one is a SiN x membrane window with 50 nm thick, and the other is a bottom chip with a 25 nm SiN x membrane window. The precursor solution was flowed into the cell by using a syringe pump. Subsequently, Sun and Zheng et al. made an ordinary carbon film-based liquid cell (Fig. 2F) to investigate the oriented attachment of Au nanoparticles [45]. Compared to graphene or carbon film-based cells, SiN x liquid cells are still highly attractive because they are strong and relatively inert and have low imaging contrast. Most importantly, the SiN x liquid cells allowed for different heating and electric bias experiments. With the recent rapid developments of Si-based fabrication and ultra-thin film technology, microelectrodes have been integrated onto the heater microchips (Fig. 2G) [46]. Due to the development of liquid cell configurations, considerable progress and notable developments have been made in the in situ liquid cell TEM investigation of the dynamic growth processes of metal-based core–shell nanostructures in real-time, which are carefully discussed. 3 The application of in situ liquid cell TEM for directly visualizing the dynamic growth processes of metal-based core–shell nanostructures 3.1 One-pot synthesis The growth of core–shell nanostructures during the one-pot approach involves homogeneous nucleation and seed-mediated [47,48]. Thus, the precursor ratios are essential for producing core–shell structure during one-pot growth. It is noted that the whole process including seed growth and seed-overgrowth occurred in the liquid cell. By systematically changing precursor ratios, the morphology, structure, and composition are investigated by in situ liquid cell TEM. For example, Liang et al. obtained different nanostructures in a static liquid cell by tuning the Fe-to-Pt ratio in the precursor solution [30]. The alloy is formed when the ratio of Fe(acac)3 and Pt(acac)2 in the precursor solution is 1.4:1 or 1:1. While the Fe:Pt ratio is 4:1, the Pt3Fe alloy nanoparticle are formed first, followed by the Fe-O shell (Fig. 3 A). EDS Mapping further confirmed the core and shell distribution (Fig. 3B). The structural evolution and corresponding fast Fourier transform (FFT) and inverse fast Fourier transform (IFFT) of the core–shell structure in Fig. 3C demonstrated the g rowing iron oxide layer is α-Fe2O3 [110], which covered the whole Fe3Pt core particle. The authors also identified two interfaces between the Pt3Fe alloy and the Fe-O shell: a coherent interface and the other is a dislocation. In addition, the atomic formation mechanism of the PtNi-O core–shell structure was also investigated by controlling the Pt-to-Ni ratio in the static liquid cell [49,50]. When the ratio of Pt to Ni was 2.5:1, the Pt3Ni alloy nanoparticles were observed. Pt3Ni-NiO core–shell nanoparticles are synthesized with a Ni-to-Pt ratio of 1.25:1. Specifically, the Pt3Ni alloy core is formed and then stopped growth, resulting from the Pt precursor's depletion. Subsequently, a Ni shell encased the core particles (Fig. 3D). Finally, the Ni shell was oxidized and transformed into NiO layers. Moreover, Pt3Ni-Ni(OH)2 core–shell structures formed at gas–liquid interfaces in liquid cells when the Ni-to-Pt ratio was 2.5: 1. The nucleation and growth site of the Ni(OH)2 shell layer is found either at the middle part or at the step edge of the existing layer (Fig. 3E). These findings suggested that in situ liquid cell TEM is a powerful platform to observe the atomic growth and dynamic processes of metal/alloy-metal oxides core–shell structure by a one-pot method. Critical questions on growth mechanisms, the role of the electron beam, precursor ratios, and even their interface could be solved. 3.2 Seed-mediated overgrowth The seed-mediated overgrowth synthesis of anisotropic nanoparticles is that the nanoparticle seed is pre-synthesized and then added to the growth solution [51–53]. Wu et al. reported the formation of a Pt-Au core–shell nanostructure using Pt seed by in situ liquid flow cell TEM [54]. The quantitative analysis illustrated the three-stage growth process: island growth, surface diffusion, and layer growth. In particular, Au was first deposited on the corners of Pt nanoparticles. Subsequently, the Au atoms diffused from corners to terraces and edges. Finally, the Pt-Au core–shell nanoparticles were formed via layer-by-layer growth of Au layers. The results are consistent with Xia’s theory, which deemed that the deposition preferred the corners due to their high surface energy[55]. Finally, the migration is from corners to terraces and edges to achieve the core–shell nanoparticles with the lower Gibbs free energy. Moreover, Sutter’s group also found that the size and shape of seed nanoparticles determined the morphology of the shells [56]. For 5 nm nanoparticles, the Au seed is wrapped in uniform Pd shells. For 5 nm or 30 nm nanoparticles, the Pd atoms were deposited at the corners and asperities of the seed, which led to the non-uniform growth of the Pd shell. Finally, the different morphologies of the Au-Pd core–shell were achieved. Using the graphene/SiN x liquid cells, the high-resolution TEM image of formation mechanisms of Au–Ag core–shell has been unraveling [57], during which the AgBr first grew and then dissolved by layer-by-layer methods, finally transformed into the Ag shell growth (Fig. 4 A). The AgBr particles already formed in solution and played an essential role in exchanging Ag+ ions. Recently, in situ liquid cell TEM describes how additives, capping agents, or small ligands control the seed-mediated overgrowth processes, which is essential for fabricating core–shell nanoparticles with tailored morphology for a broad range of applications [58–60]. For example, the overgrowth process of Au-Ag core–shell nanocubes was imaged with ascorbic acid (AA) and a low concentration of cetyltrimethylammonium bromide (CTAB) [58]. The identical nanostructures formed via nuclei coalescence and monomer attachment. In the early stages, only AA mediates the reaction. The CTAB controls deposition rate and surface diffusion by suppressing higher surface energy faces. The final morphology is cuboctahedron in the presence of insufficient availability of CTAB. The role of AA has also been reconsidered in the anisotropic growth of Au-Ag core–shell nanoparticles, which stabilize the {100} facets of Au (Fig. 4B) [59]. With the addition of AA, the Ag atoms deposit on an Au bipyramid along the 〈110〉 direction via homonucleation. The growth pathway transforms bipyramids into nanorods without AA. In addition, the two-growth pathways in precursor solutions have been unraveled using a carbon film liquid cell during the formation of Au-Ag core–shell nanobipyramids. [60] Without adding poly(vinyl)pyrrolidone (PVP), Ag atoms deposit directly onto Au nanoparticles. With the addition of PVP, the Ag nanocrystals adsorb onto Au nanoparticles via nucleus coalescence. Furthermore, in situ studies could describe how thiol additives (like L-cysteine) control the morphological evolution of Au nanorods in Fig. 4(C) [61]. The ligand of thiols binds to the Au nanorods and reduces the Ag deposition rate. Finally, the Au-Ag sawtooth structure formed, which is the thermodynamically controlled process. Without the thiols, the Ag fast-deposit Au nanorods result in the fourfold symmetric wings on {110} side facets, which is a kinetically controlled process. These advances use different chemical additives (AA and L-cysteine) or capping agents (CTAB and PVP) to alter the reaction kinetics. The mediated overgrowth in the presence of additives could provide new strategies for tuning the shape and structure of core–shell nanoparticles. Besides, the small ligands (such as Br-) also control the seed-mediated overgrowth process and influence the final morphology of core–shell nanoparticles. For example, Chi’s group integrated in situ liquid cell TEM to capture the atomistic nucleation and growth of Pt on Pd nanocrystals by tuning the small ligands (Br-) and precursor concentration [32]. Without the addition of Br-, Pt atoms are deposited on the faces of a Pd cube. With Br-, Pt atoms preferred to nucleate and grow from faces rather than corners. At a high precursor concentration, the Pt clusters form by the self-nucleation method, and the non-uniform shell is produced. The results demonstrated that the Pd-Pt core–shell cubes with uniform Pt layers were achieved in a low concentration precursor with Br−. Temperature is another critical factor for determining the metal-based core–shell structure produced during seed-mediated growth [62]. Earlier reports have shown that the final shape of the core–shell structure is affected by surface diffusion and deposition of shell atoms [31]. For example, in situ liquid flow cell TEM has been used to observe the formation of the Au-Pd core–shell structures at different reaction temperatures (Fig. 4D). At 23 °C, a few Pd atoms or small nanoparticles diffuse and deposit on the tips and later on the corners of the Au nanorods. The slow surface diffusion led to an arrow-headed Au-Pd core–shell structure. Pd atoms diffused and absorbed on the tips of Au nanorods and later on the side facets at an operating temperature of 80 °C. The fast surface diffusion from tip to {100} and {110} sides led to the formation of a cuboidal Au-Pd core–shell structure. Control experiments suggested that AA could reduce Pd2+ and promote Pd overgrowth. The final morphology depends on the competition between the deposition and surface diffusion rates at different temperatures. Reaction temperatures from low to high can switch the Pd shell growth from the kinetically controlled process to a thermodynamically controlled process. In a word, the in situ liquid cell TEM directly observed the entire overgrowth process of seeds into the different core–shell nanostructures with different conditions. The final morphologies of these nanostructures depended on the size and shape of the seeds. In addition, the additives or ligands also influenced the final morphologies by changing the local surface energies. Besides, the temperature altered the surface diffusion and deposition of atoms and affected the final morphologies. More importantly, the in situ experimental results were consistent with the ex situ experiment and traditional growth theory [4,45,53]. 3.3 Galvanic replacement Galvanic replacement reactions offer an alternative way of transforming nanoparticles into core–shell nanostructures [63]. The principle of galvanic replacement reactions is that metal ions with higher oxidation potentials are reduced by oxidizing another metal with lower oxidation potentials [64,65]. In the past, the galvanic replacement has been studied by characterizing the products ex-situ that arise from the reaction at different stages. In situ liquid cell TEM has recently been shown to elucidate the development and transformation mechanisms of galvanic replacement reactions [66,67]. There are two half-reactions in the Ag-Pd system: Ag oxidation (Ag0(s) + Cl− → AgCl(s) + e−) and Pd2+ reduction ((PdCl4)2− + 2e → Pd0(s) + 4Cl−). The porous Ag-Pd alloy nanocages are formed from Ag templates in aqueous PdCl2 solutions. A control experiment demonstrates that OH accelerates Ag oxidation. The isopropanol scavenger could modify galvanic reactions and promote the growth of Pd on the Ag cores. Finally, an Ag-Pd core–shell nanostructure forms. In situ liquid cell TEM could also modify galvanic replacement reactions in their native solution environment [68]. For example, Han’s group demonstrated in situ liquid flow cell TEM the dynamic galvanic replacement mechanisms of twinned metallic nanowires in Fig. 5 (A). In the beginning, the Au nanoparticles appear and surround an Ag nanowire. Owing to the different standard reduction potentials of Au/AuCl4 and Ag+/Ag pairs, the Au nanoparticles/ions adhere onto the edge of the Ag nanowire and generate a galvanic replacement reaction. The pit grows and expands along the cross-section of the sidewall in a nanowire. The tubular structure forms after 12 s. The EDS mapping confirms that the elemental distributions are Ag, Cl, and Au. The DFT calculations indicated that Ag atoms at the twin boundary are first removed due to the lowest energy of the (111) twin boundary (−0.29 eV). Later, the replacements of Ag atoms occur on the crystal layers neighboring the twin boundaries due to their energy (−0.19 eV). This work is good for understanding the galvanic replacement processes and designing the hollow structures. Moreover, a systematic study of ligand effects during galvanic replacement has been carried out. For example, Tan and co-workers used in situ liquid cell TEM to observe the galvanic replacement reaction of Ag nanocube in the mix solution, including ethylenediaminetetraacetic acid (EDTA) disodium salt and chloroauric acid (Fig. 5B) [69]. At the beginning stage, the (100) faces of nanocube are etching. Simultaneously, the Au layers deposited the corners of the nanocube via particle coalescence and monomer attachment. Finally, the Ag-Au bowl-shaped structure formed. The ligand EDTA slowed down galvanic chemical reactions so that quantitative analysis could come true while the reactions happened. In situ liquid cell STEM also studied the formation of the Ag-Au nanostructures with or without ligands [31]. Without ligands, Ag-Au galvanic replacement occurred, and the nanocages with Au-rich formed in methanol (Fig. 5C). While high concentrations of the ligand dimethyl-amine (DMA) reduced the deposition of Au, resulting in partially hollow structures (Fig. 5C). Additionally, the study demonstrated that the KI could tune the morphology of the resulting nanostructures while not influence the Au deposition rates. Notably, the addition of DMA and KI to the reaction slows it down and shifts the growth regime from galvanic to direct synthesis Ag-Au core–shell nanostructures. The above studies demonstrated that ligands or chemical additives play an essential role in tuning metal-based core–shell nanostructures' composition and morphology during the nanoscale galvanic replacement reaction. 3.4 Kirkendall effect Except for the galvanic replacement, the metal-based core–shell hollow structure could be prepared by the Kirkendall effect. Yin and his colleagues first observed the Kirkendall phenomenon in the colloidal synthesis of hollow nanostructures because of the different diffusion rates of atoms in a diffusion couple [70]. Then, steady-state bulk diffusion or surface diffusion-mediated growth was introduced to explain this phenomenon. Most studies of the Kirkendall phenomenon were based on previous experiments. The growth dynamics of a hollow structure are still unknown because of a lack of direct observations [71,72]. Recently, liquid cell TEM was used to reveal the formation of a hollow structure of bismuth oxide (Bi2O3) at 180 °C through the Kirkendall effect [63]. As shown in Fig. 6 (A), Bi nanoparticles first nucleated and grew by coalescence and monomer attachment. Sequentially, a thin Bi2O3 layer formed at the nanoparticle surface. Later, the void developed at the interface between Bi and Bi2O3. The bismuth core appeared, and a non-uniform shell formed due to different diffusion pathways of Bi at the interface. The work also calculated that the diffusion coefficient of Bi was 3–4 times of magnitude more significant than the self-diffusion coefficient of bulk according to the analysis of the Bi2O3 growth. Besides, the galvanic replacement and Kirkendall effect can couple and form complex hollow structures [33]. In situ TEM imaged the Ag-Au hollow structures in a flow liquid cell at different temperatures. At 23 °C, the Au shell forms via galvanic replacement. Then a clear gap was imaged between the Ag nanocube and the shell during the Kirkendall hollowing process. Nanopores appeared due to the collapsed shell. The residual core undergoes the second galvanic replacement (Fig. 6B). At 90 °C, two voids arise and merge to produce a single larger void. The new void propagates across the nanocube until hollow nanostructures ultimately form (Fig. 6C). However, the hollow nanostructures start at the corners of Ag nanocubes via galvanic replacement and the Kirkendall effect. Thus, it is concluded that the particles' temperature, defects, and sizes drastically changed the diffusion rate and finally affected the Kirkendall effect. 3.5 Corrosion or dealloying The corrosion of metal nanocrystals has been used to form metal-based hollow nanostructures [74]. Wu’s group reported the galvanic etching and halogen-induced etching of Pd@Pt core–shell nanoparticles with different shapes using a flow liquid cell, as shown in Fig. 7 (A) [75]. The etching starts at the corners of a regular cube. Subsequently, the four corners produce small voids. As voids grow larger, the Pd cubic core etches, and the Pt cage forms. Under different pressures inside and outside, the Pt cage shrunk into a hollow nanostructure. The etching also started at the corners for a corner defected cube, and the four voids appeared at corners. Later, the two voids at the upper-left and lower-right corners grew larger and coalesced into a nanochannel, but the other two voids did not change. For a face defected cube, the etching started with a terrace defect. The cavity nucleates grew and expanded the two sides of the cube. Then the local curvature with low coordinated sites promoted the cavity evolution via halogen etching. Finally, a hollow Pt cage formed. Fig. 7(B) also summarized the site-dependent etching rates of three nanoparticle stages (Stage III > Stage I > Stage II) and indicated etching preferentially from corners due to low coordination numbers. The study also identifies two competing etching paths in defected cubes: slow galvanic etching at corners site and fast halogen-induced etching at defected sites. The optimized Pd@Pt core–shell nanocubes with different Pt layers are designed based on the in situ liquid cell TEM experiments by redistributing Pt atoms on the corner and terraces sites [35,76]. The strategy keeps the same Pt shell and protects the corrosion sites. As shown in Fig. 7(C-E), the low etching rate of Pd@Pt with 7–8 layers was measured due to the fewer Pd channels in Pt layers at the initial etching stage. Later, a fast etching appeared because of high local curvature. The Pd@Pt with 7–8 layers showed the best ORR activity. The work is a typical example of building a bridge between in situ liquid cell TEM study and practical application. To understand how strain influences the corrosion dynamics, the same group also studied the corrosion of Pd@Pt core–shell octahedral nanoparticles, which start from the defects on the corners and terrace [77]. The early and later corrosion process depends on the local strain and evolving curvature. This work provides important guidance for designing the strains of nanoparticles to obtain corrosion-resistant electrocatalysts and builds a bridge between in situ experiments and practical application. In situ liquid cell TEM has imaged the template etching and shell formation for metalorganic framework (MOF) nanoparticles [78-80]. Wang et al. used cubic and rhombic dodecahedron (RD) ZIF-8 as templates to reveal the conversion of MOF into hollow Layered Double Hydroxide (LDH) nanocages in the metal nitrite precursor [80]. A mixed solution of water and ethanol-containing Co(NO3)2 was injected into a flow liquid cell to decrease the electron beam effect. In the 5 mg mL−1 Co(NO3)2 solution (VEtOH/VH2O = 0.5), uniform etching of ZIF-8 nanocubes occurred, whereas the shell of LDH increased. The nanocubes were completely transformed into ZnCo LDH nanocages (Fig. 8 A). The ZIF-8 nanocubes were etched and promptly dissolved with 10 mg mL-1 Co(NO3)2 solution, preventing uniform LDH layer formation. For RD ZIF-8 nanoparticles (Fig. 8B), uniform etching of {110} facets resulted from shrinking. The RD LDH nanocages were produced after the inner MOF was etched. Control experiments showed the nanocubes and RD nanoparticles etched quickly with higher water content (VEtOH/VH2O ≤ 0.25). The work also explored the formation of complex shell-in-shell LDH nanocages. As shown in Fig. 8(C), the RD ZIF-8 was etched first, while an outer LDH shell rapidly grew in the Co(NO3)2 solution. After the etching of the ZIF-67 core, the new LDH shell is formed. The EDS mapping (Fig. 8D) confirmed the formation of shell-in-shell LDH nanostructures. The dealloying in the alloy through chemical and electrochemical etching has been studied using in situ liquid cell STEM [36,81-83]. As shown in (Fig. 9 A), the electrochemical etching produced nanoparticles with more uniform pore sizes than the chemical etching [26]. The nanoparticle porosity could be tuned by altering the electrochemical potential (Fig. 9B). At the beginning of both etching methods, the surface of the alloy produced the Au-rich passivation layer, which is suitable for retaining a shell-like structure. Finally, the alloy shell transformed into a porous shell after the etching away of Ag. The effect of temperature on the electrochemical etching of PtNi alloy nanoparticles has been explored using heating and biasing modified SiN x liquid cells [83]. The electrochemical Ni etching process was summarized: the first stage is the formation of passivated native Ni oxide; the second stage is the active dissolution of Ni; the last stage is the formation of Ni sulfate from ions. The Electrochemical Ni dissolution rate is faster at 70 °C than at 23 °C. The etching rate and dissolution potential during the electrochemical Ni etching process could change under different temperature control. It is anticipated that the temperature-controlled electrochemical cell will provide opportunities to explore other electrochemical reactions. 4 Summary, challenges, and perspectives In this review, the utilization of in situ liquid phase TEM studies for monitoring the dynamic growth processes of metal-based core–shell nanostructures has been carefully summarized. The in situ liquid cell TEM/STEM techniques bring new observations of reaction processes and provide in-depth knowledge of the growth mechanisms of various metal-based core–shell nanostructures. Among those studies, in situ heating, flow, and biasing liquid cell TEM observations have made significant contributions to our understanding of growth pathways and phase transformations during dynamic processes or reactions under their working conditions. Despite the remarkable advancements made by in situ liquid cell TEM, considerable challenges remain. The pressing challenges and future research directions are proposed below (Fig. 10 ). First, electron beam effects and imaging resolution are significant challenges for liquid cell TEM. The roles of electron beam were not only for imaging but also for promoting the formation of core–shell structures [84–86]. For example, hydrated electrons induced by the electron beam reduce the chloropalladate complexes in a containing Au nanoparticle seeds. The growth rate depends on the beam excitation [56]. More recently, the electron beam decomposed hexamethylenetetramine and induced crystallization of ZnO shells. Finally, the amorphous ZnO shells were transformed into crystalline.[87] Besides, the high electron beam dosage rates also led to local heating, radiation damage, and even gaseous products [8,88]. For the side effect of the electron beam, the radiolysis is the most critical beam damage mechanism, which leads to the formation and expansion of bubble and other unwanted reactions [89–92]. Thanks to the recent development in (S)TEM, better image contrast can be achieved at a much lower dose. Further development of low-dose optimized electron microscopy techniques will be essential. Using low-dose imaging conditions, combined with a low accumulated electron dose, and optimized flow rates of solutions (for flow cells) allows for observation of the formation of core–shell structures [93]. Apart from using a lower dose, adding scavenger molecules also reduces radiolysis damage. Therefore, in situ liquid cell TEM/STEM should consider reducing the accelerating voltage or electron beam dosage rates. Besides, using different membrane materials (such as graphene) was reported to reduce beam damage, allowing a higher dose by one magnitude for imaging [94]. The graphene and thin SiN x window-based static liquid cells achieve an atomic resolution comparable to TEM [57,95–97]. For example, Andreas Hutzler et al. introduced the new graphene/SiN x liquid cells, which combine the advantages of graphene-and silicon-based architectures [97]. Using the graphene/SiN x liquid cells, the formation mechanisms of Au-Ag core–shell have been unraveled with high-resolution TEM. The AgBr is first formed and then dissolved by layer-by-layer methods, which promote the Ag shell growth [57]. Notably, it is still challenging to view emotional reactions with high resolution in an electrochemical liquid cell and flow liquid cells. Second, from the aspect of TEM advancement, the newly developed aberration-corrected S/TEM could provide compositional information and local electronic structure of core–shell with Å spatial resolution [82,98]. Additionally, some spectroscopic analysis techniques (such as EELS) could provide chemical component analysis with high spatial resolution [99,100]. The double energy-filtered imaging STEM technique could achieve 0.01 eV energy resolution. The fast HAADF-STEM tomography could decrease the acquisition time [101,102]. Recently, Muller and co-workers developed a new electron microscope pixel-array detector (EMPAD) to achieve the best resolution of 0.04 nm under 80 Kv [103]. The breakthrough could enhance image resolution and contrast and bring new opportunities to the in situ TEM for imaging compositions and even bonding evolutions of core–shell structures. Third, from instrumentation development, designing new liquid cells with the mixing of two or more components (optics, heater, magnetic et al.) and the corresponding in situ TEM holders are needed, which would help capture other phenomena that can quantitatively measurements of core–shell structures. Such as the recent development of 4 D ultrafast TEM with short electron pulse shows a 10 ps imaging speed and 10 nm spatial resolution, which could capture ultra-fast thermal expansions and phase transitions [104-106]. Fourth, from the aspect of data collection and analysis, massive datasets produced for in situ TEM require a data-intensive technique to deal with [107,108]. Such as, the recent development of machine learning could resolve 3 D morphologies by in situ liquid cell TEM for low signal-to-noise ratio data sets and low-dose electron tomography [109–113]. Fifth, from the aspect of the systems on the growth of core–shell nanostructures, many factors can affect the growth processes and result in different products, such as pH, temperature, precursor ratios, seeds’ morphologies, additives, capping agents, small ligands et al. Moreover, introducing biasing electrodes or light into the liquid cell can change (positively or negatively) the products obtained from in situ liquid cell TEM [83,105]. Besides, the electron beam also alter the growth pathway of core–shell nanostructures [50,114]. For example, monitoring the formation of metal(oxide) @silica-based heterogeneous yolk-shell nanostructures has been exploited using in situ liquid cell STEM [114]. The work found the optimized imaging conditions to study the wet etching of silica-based core–shell nanoparticles. The depositing enough energy could alter the siloxane network through electron irradiation. Finally, the metal(oxide)@silica- based core–shell nanospheres transformed into the yolk–shell nanoparticles after the inhomogeneous etching. Last but not least, the combination of in situ liquid cell TEM with other in situ characterization techniques (small-angle x-ray scattering (SAXS), Raman spectroscopy, mass spectroscopy, Fourier transform infrared spectroscopy etc.) can provide a more comprehensive image of the ongoing growth process and material evolution of core–shell nanostructures in environments mimicking reaction conditions [115–119]. For example, Sun’s group used the in situ SAXS technique and ab initio structural modeling to explore the nanoscale Kirkendall process of metal nanoparticles into hollow metal oxide nanoshells. More importantly, the 3D structure models were built for the evolution process [119]. As a fasting-growing technique, in situ liquid cell TEM will boost understanding of the intrinsic mechanism of the dynamic structure–property relationship. The advanced multifunctional liquid cells, unprecedented high-resolution imaging, and fast data detection and analysis may capture more details of growing core–shell nanostructures in the energy conversion and storage fields [119-125]. Zheng, X. Lu, K. He. J. Energy Chem. 68 (2022) 454-493. Junyu Zhang is currently a Research Supervisor of Laboratory and Equipment Management Department of Huaqiao University, China. He received his Ph.D. degree under the supervision of Prof. Shi-Gang Sun and Prof. Hong-Gang Liao in 2019 from Xiamen University, China. He received his BSc degree in 2011 from Fujian Agriculture and Forestry University and Master degree in 2015 from Fuzhou University, respectively. His research interests include the assembly of hybrid semiconductors and metal-based novel energy materials by in situ liquid TEM. Qiaobao Zhang is currently a Professor at Xiamen University, China. He obtained his Ph.D. degree from the City University of Hong Kong in 2016. He joined Prof. Meilin Liu’s group as a visiting Ph.D. student at Georgia Institute of Technology in 2015. His current research focuses on the fundamental issues relevant to energy storage systems including Li/Na/K ion batteries, especially on the key electrode materials, interfacial properties and in situ techniques. Till now, he has published more than 120 papers, twenty-one of which are highly cited, which attracted more than 9000 citations with an h-index of 52.

coredata.dc:description: Metal-based core-shell nanostructures have garnered enduring interest due to their unique properties and functionalities. However, their growth and transformation mechanisms in liquid media remain largely unknown because they lack direct observation of the dynamic growth process with high spatial and temporal resolution. Developing the in situ liquid cell transmission electron microscopy (TEM) technique offers unprecedented real-time imaging and spectroscopy capabilities to directly track the evolution of structural and chemical transformation of metal-based core–shell nanostructures in liquid media under their working condition. Here, this review highlights recent progress in utilizing in situ liquid cell TEM characterization technique in investigating the dynamic evolution of material structure and morphology of metal-based core–shell nanostructures at the nano/atomic scale in real-time. A brief introduction of the development of liquid cells for in situ TEM is first given. Subsequently, recent advances in in situ liquid cell TEM for the fundamental study of growth mechanisms of metal based core–shell nanostructures are discussed. Finally, the challenge and future developments of metal-based core–shell nanostructures for in situ liquid cell TEM are proposed. Our review is anticipated to inspire ongoing interest in revealing unseen growth dynamics of core–shell nanostructures by in situ liquid cell TEM technique.
